warmup.content: # Warmup --- Let's begin with a quick review of what we did last Tuesday. #### Task 1: Create and Deploy --- Using the technique we learned on Tuesday, create a simple website from scratch and deploy it to the internet view GitHub Pages. **REQUIREMENTS** * Create a folder called **mySecondWebsite**. All your relevant code should go inside this folder. * It should have **one** html file only (**QUESTION**: what should that file be called...?) * Your HTML file can be simple, just a **"Hello, Wrold"** should suffice (use the **h1** tag). * Remember to use proper HTML formatting. What tags must you have in **all** HTML files? Include them. * Deploy your site to the internet with GitHub. **REMINDER** * Here is how you **[deploy a sample page](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wfBOrn3IzLw)** to the internet. #### Task 2: Simple Markup --- Create a valid HTML page and add the proper markup so that it appears **similar** to this: **REQUIREMENTS** * Note that we require your version to look **similar**, not exactly the same. * In general, do not worry about getting the fonts, borders, spacings correct. We will learn about that eventually. * Focus specifically on getting the **tags** correct. For example, what tag would you need for the title of the article? How about for the content? Etc * Deploy your page to GitHub just like you did in Task 1.

web-developer-tools.content:
# Web Developer Tools --- Web developer tools are your best friend. #### How to Access * You can right click anywhere on Chrome and pick **Inspect** option. * In the top menu bar, you can choose **View** > **Developer** > **Developer Tools** #### The Options
#### Elements * Elements are the HTML tags that your created, but visualized as the browser interprets them. * Note how the elements contain HTML tag information (on the left) but also CSS data (on the right).
#### Console * The console contains output from javascript code this is being run by the site. * The console will display **log statements** (basically, small messages that the developer writes into his/her code while testing) and it will display **errors** (in red). * Console is supremely useful in debugging the code you write.
#### Sources * Sources contains all the javascript, css, and HTML files that are being loaded by the entire webpage. * This includes the actual code that you wrote but **also** includes libraries and services like **Google Analytics**, **iframes**, etc.
#### Network * The network tab is super useful - it displays **every** **single** resource the webpage loads. * Resources include things like **html files**, **javascript files**, **CSS files**, **images**, **videos**, **fonts**, etc * You can also see how long each resource took and **when** the browser started to load that resource * Finally, you can click into each of the resource lines to view a more detailed account of the **http** request that was sent and the response the browser got back.
#### Application * The application tab shows you data relating to persistent storage and caching. * **Persistent storage** includes stuff like **cookies**, **local storage**, and **session storage**. * If can see exactly what information other sites are using to track your actions on a particular page (generally, most of these stored data items are not malicious, but very interesting to look at) * If you'd like you can also remove stored items from your session using this UI> * Furthermore, you can see what pages and resources the browser is caching (for faster reloads) * Finally, all resources that you saw in the **network** tab are reproduced here as just files that you can view or download.
